title: The Drug Reaction That Almost Killed Me

content: There’s some amount of risk when you try a new medication for fibromyalgia. It seems like all medicines come with possible side effects, for example.
There’s the threat of a bad reaction – even an allergic one. The experience I’m about to tell you about wouldn’t be called an allergic reaction (anaphylaxis), but it certainly threatened my life.

I’ve been living with depression since a traumatic event in 2005. My exact diagnosis is “recurrent major depressive disorder without psychotic features.” I take medications, go to weekly counseling, see my psychiatrist every month, stay close to my support system, and work hard every day to manage my symptoms through various self-care techniques.

At the time of the story I’m about to tell you (circa 2021), I’d finally shepherded all of my depression symptoms into a cage and locked them up. One or two got loose once in a while, but in general, I was in a neutral place. Even a good one, at times.

content: I’ve tried several medications in my quest to cope with fibromyalgia. Some worked for me. Most didn’t. Fibro management is a lifelong experiment, I suppose.
With one medication, I had what you could call a “bad” reaction. No, I didn’t get sick. No, my throat didn’t close up. There was no rash or swelling, and I could breathe. There was no drug allergy.
But! The medication put my life in danger.
Within an hour of taking that first pill, I was suicidal. I went from a neutral mood to a depressed mood to “I can’t take this anymore” in less than 60 minutes.

I was working from home at the time. It was around 9 a.m. and I was sitting in my office, at my desk, editing or writing something or other. At first, I didn’t notice that the pill I’d taken for the first time that morning had unlocked the cage in which I’d stowed away my depression symptoms. But then the negative thoughts got loud enough to hear and, wow, they got dark fast:

content: “My fibromyalgia pain hasn’t gotten worse in a while. I bet it’ll get bad tomorrow. I’ll probably have to miss work and if I miss too much work, I’ll get fired!”
“How much weight have I gained in the past year? 30 pounds? My family is probably embarrassed to be seen with me in public.”
“I’m really bad at my job. My boss is probably writing me up right now. I deserve to get fired.”
“What do I have to look forward to after work? Nothing. I’m depressed, lonely, fatigued, and in pain. What a lousy life.”
“This is too hard. All I do is work, sleep, and fight my depression. And how many friends do I really have? Nobody would want this life.”
“I can’t take this. It’s too much. I hate my life. I don’t want to feel like this anymore. I have enough pills to—”
Stop.
STOP.
I froze. Literally, in my seat. And then I picked up my phone and called for help.

content: Years ago, when my depression was at its worst, I came up with a game plan just in case I ever felt suicidal. I didn’t expect to need it, but made it just in case. That morning, when I was considering swallowing every pill in my house, I immediately put my plan into action.
I called my counselor. I called my therapist. I called my close friends. And I called the suicide line.
988, the suicide and crisis lifeline, is available in the United States 24/7. You can talk to someone immediately, for free.
In addition to the calls I prayed, took deep breaths, journaled, and did some other self-care activities.
I survived. I stayed on the phone with various people in my life until I knew that I was safe. I know that I have support and a plan that works.
I hope you’ll make your own plan. Remember to dial 911 if the reaction is physical, 988 if it’s mental/emotional. Don’t hesitate.
